A pillar from Mathura referring to Chandragupta has recently been dated to 388 AD.[PARAGRAPH:2]Chandragupta's daughter Prabhavati, by his other queen Kuberanaga, a Naga princess, was married to the powerful Vakataka king Rudrasena II.[PARAGRAPH:2]His greatest victory was his victory over the Shaka-Kshatrapa dynasty and annexation of their kingdom in Gujarat, by defeating their last ruler Rudrasimha III.[PARAGRAPH:2]His son-in-law, the Vakataka king Rudrasena II, died fortuitously after a very short reign in 390 AD, following which Prabhavatigupta ruled the Vakataka kingdom as a regent on behalf of his two sons. During this twenty-year period the Vakataka realm was practically a part of the Gupta empire. The geographical location of the Vakataka kingdom allowed Chandragupta to take the opportunity to defeat the Western Kshatrapas once for all. Many historians refer to this period as the Vakataka-Gupta age.[PARAGRAPH:2]Chandragupta II the Great controlled a vast empire, from the mouth of the Ganges to the mouth of the Indus River and from what is now North Pakistan down to the mouth of the Narmada. Pataliputra continued to be the capital of his huge empire but Ujjain too became a sort of second capital. The large number of beautiful gold coins issued by the Gupta dynasty are a testament to the imperial grandeur of that age. Chandragupta II also started producing silver coins in the Shaka tradition.[PARAGRAPH:2]Faxian (Wade-Giles Fa-hsien) was the first of three great Chinese pilgrims who visited India from the fifth to the seventh centuries AD, in search of knowledge, manuscripts and relics. He arrived during the reign of Chandragupta II and gave a general description of North India at that time. Among the other things, he reported about the absence of capital punishment, the lack of a poll-tax and land tax. Most citizens did not consume onions, garlic, meat, and wine.[PARAGRAPH:2]Culturally, the reign of Chandragupta II marked a Golden Age. This is evidenced by later reports of the presence of a circle of poets known as the Nine Gems in his court. The greatest among them was Kalidasa, who authored numerous immortal pieces of literature including The Recognition of Shakuntala. The others were the Sanskrit grammarian Amara Sinha and the astronomer-mathematician Varahamihira.[PARAGRAPH:2]The next day after the Hindu festival Diwali is called Padwa or Varshapratipada, which marks the coronation of King Vikramaditya. The Hindu Vikram-Samvat calendar was apparently started on this day and this day is celebrated as New Year's Day in Nepal where Vikram Sambat is the official calendar there, and some places in India. But, Vikram-Samvat calender is from 57 BC. So, there was someother king by name Vikram, who started this calender.[PARAGRAPH:2]Shak-Samvat is synchronised with the Shak-Samvat calendar, which starts around April. This calendar was initiated by Gautamiputra Satakarni who defeated the Saka king Vikramaditya, thus starting the Shalivahana era or Shaka Calendar.

[H1]Jingu[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Empress of Japan[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived: [\BOLD]c. 169 AD - 269 AD[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][TAB][PARAGRAPH:1]No firm dates can be assigned to this historical figure's life or reign. Jingu is regarded by historians as a "legendary" figure because of the paucity of information about her, which does not necessarily imply that no such person ever existed. There is insufficient material available for further verification and study. Jingu's name before her accession to the Chrysanthemum throne - if indeed she did ascend the throne - would have been Okinagatarashi-hime.[PARAGRAPH:1]Although the final resting place of this legendary regent/sovereign remains unknown, Jingu's officially designated misasagi or tomb can be visited today at Misasagi-cho om Nara. This kofun-type Imperial tomb is characterized by a keyhole-shaped island located within a wide, water-filled moat.[PARAGRAPH:1]In 1881, Empress Jingu became the first woman to be featured on the Japanese banknote.

[H1]Sapadzides[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sovereign in Bactria[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reigned: [\BOLD]about 20 BC - 1 AD[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]We know very little about the the sovereign Sapadbizes. There is no literature by the persians, the greek, the romans or hardly by the chinese. The only testemonies left by the Yuezhi are simple coins, showing his face and name, found in Uzbekistan and northern Afghanistan.[PARAGRAPH:2]Coins have been found, with 2 other kings, "Agezilles" and a nameless one, who are thought to be his inheritors and part of the dynasty founded by himself, the Sapadbians. There is a map on the back of another coin, show the eastern part of the Oxus river (also known as Amu Darja) and several cities, which perhaps was the realm ruled by the Sapadbians. It would have been bordered to the west by the Parthians, to the south by the Indo-Parthians and to the north by other tribes of the Yuezhi. [PARAGRAPH:2]The realm of Sapadbizes was probably under Persian influence. One coin shows Sapadbizes on the front and a winged lion on the back. Such creatures are well-known in persian literature and culture, and its name "Nana" is very likely to "Nanaja", the Sumerian fertility goddess and lunar deity.[PARAGRAPH:2]The only possible documented source of Sapadbizes' existence comes from the Chinese. They wrote of the "Yabgu of Kao-fu" who could be identical to Sapadbizes. He was told to conquer the other 4 Yabgus of the Yuezhi to build an empire, called Kuei-shung by the chinese. This very empire was conquered by the Parthians in the first century BC.
TEXT.German: [H1]Sapadzides[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Herrscher in Baktrien[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Herrschte [\BOLD]ca. 20 v.Chr. - 1 n.Chr[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2]Über den Herrscher Sapadzides ist so gut wie nichts bekannt. Es gibt keine namentlichen Nachweise in persischen, griechischen, römischen oder chinesischen Quellen. Die einzigen Zeugnisse, die der Nachwelt hinterlassen wurden, sind Münzen, die vereinzelt in Usbekistan und Nordafghanistan ausgegraben wurden.[PARAGRAPH:2]Es wurden Münzen von zwei anderen Herrschern gefunden, Agezilles und ein Unbenannter, die den Gefunden in solchem Maße ähneln, dass man ihnen eine Beziehung zu Sapadbizes nicht absprechen kann. So wird davon ausgegangen, dass er eine Dynastie begründete, die Sapadbizen, denen mindestens jene zwei Herrscher ebenfalls entstammen. Auf einer anderen Münze wurde eine Landkarte entdeckt, die haputsächlich das Gebiet um den Oxus (auch Amudarja genannt) zeigen, das als Herrschaftsgebiet der Sapadbizen identifiziert wurde. Im Osten begrenzt durch das Land der Parther, im Süden durch die Indo-Parther, ist die Grenze im Norden unklar. Dort gab es einzelne Stämme der Yuezhi, denen auch Sapadbizes entstammt; in wieweit sie zusammenlebten, lässt sich nicht sagen.[PARAGRAPH:2]Manche Forscher behaupten, dass das Reich Sapadbizes' stark unter perischem Einfluss stand. Auf einer Münze ist, neben Sapadbizes selbst, ein geflügelter Löwe zu sehen. Nicht nur, dass so eine Kreatur in der perischen Kultur häufig vorkommt, wird sie auch "Nana" genannt, dass auffällige Ähnlichkeiten mit "Nanja" hat, der alten sumerischen Fruchtbarkeits- und Mondgöttin. Weitere Münzen, die in der gleichen Gegend gefunden wurden, zeigen den Partherkönig Phraates IV.; eine Kultur würde einen fremden König nur dann abbilden, wenn sie entweder sehr enge Verbündete gewesen wären, oder dessen Vasall, so Forscher.[PARAGRAPH:2]Die einzige mögliche schriftliche Quelle, die von ihm bekannt ist, stammt aus China. Dort wird von einem "Yabgu von Kao-fu" berichtet, der möglicherweise mit Sapadbizes identisch ist. Dieser soll die anderen vier Yabgus der Yuezhi besiegt haben und so ein Reich geformt haben (in den chinesischen Quellen Kuei-shuang genannt), das irgendwann im 1. Jahrhundert vor Christus perischer Vasall wurde.

TEXT.English: [H1]Antigonus I Monophthalmus[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Founder of the Antigonid Dynasty[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Reigned: [\BOLD]323 BC - 301 BC[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Antigonus I Monophthalmus ("Antigonus the One-eyed", 382 BC - 301 BC), son of Philip from Elimeia, was a Macedonian nobleman, general, and satrap under Alexander the Great. During his early life he served under Philip II, and he was a major figure in the Wars of the Diadochi after Alexander's death, declaring himself king in 306 BC and establishing the Antigonid dynasty.

[TAB]The term "barbarian" was created by the Greeks; it was originally used to denote any foreigner. Since then it has gained a more negative connotation, and it is commonly applied to civilizations deemed "inferior" to one's own. The Chinese, for instance, thought of all foreign cultures - everybody from the Manchus to the Turks to the Europeans - as barbarians. Rome applied it to the Huns and the Germanic tribes, as well as to the more advanced Gauls.[PARAGRAPH:1]In Civilization IV, the term denotes people that are not part of any organized civilization appearing in the game, but are instead old-style hunter-gatherers who prey on the "weak" civilized world. Though some barbarians may have acquired fairly advanced weaponry - swords and axes, for example - and though they may occasionally capture or even build their own cities, they remain at heart brigandic nomads, destroying everything that comes in their path. Barbarians cannot be bargained with or appeased: they must be destroyed - before they destroy you!
TEXT.French: [TAB]Le terme "Barbare" est à l'origine un critère linguistique utilisé par les Grecs pour désigner toute personne étrangère à la civilisation grecque. Depuis, ce terme a pris une connotation péjorative et s'applique aux civilisations jugées "inférieures". Les Chinois, par exemple, considéraient toutes les cultures étrangères, des Mandchous aux Turcs en passant par les Européens, comme des barbares. Rome utilisait ce terme pour désigner les Huns, les Gaulois et les tribus germaniques.[PARAGRAPH:2]Dans Civilization IV, le terme "Barbares" désigne des gens qui ne font partie d'aucune civilisation organisée du jeu. Il s'agit de chasseurs-cueilleurs qui n'ont pas peur de s'attaquer au monde civilisé. Bien que certains barbares aient pu acquérir un armement assez avancé, avec notamment des épées et des haches, et bien qu'ils puissent à l'occasion capturer ou même fonder leurs propres villes, ils restent avant tout des "bandits-nomades", détruisant tout sur leur passage. Il est impossible de négocier avec des barbares ni même de les apaiser : il faut les éliminer avant qu'ils ne vous éliminent !
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Begriff "Barbar" kommt aus dem Griechischen und bezeichnete in seiner ursprünglichen Bedeutung alle Nichtgriechen. Seither haftete dem Wort allerdings eine immer negativere Assoziation an und heute wird es im Allgemeinen als Bezeichnung für primitivere, "unterlegenere" Zivilisationen verwendet. Die Chinesen betrachteten beispielsweise alle fremden Kulturen - wirklich alle, von den Manchus über die Türken bis hin zu den Europäern - als Barbaren. Rom benutzte den Begriff für die Hunnen und die germanischen Stämme sowie für die immerhin etwas fortschrittlicheren Gallier.[PARAGRAPH:2]In Civilization IV sind mit den "Barbaren" Völker gemeint, die keiner der organisierten Zivilisationen im Spiel angehören, sondern eher in die Kategorie "Jäger und Sammler" eingeordnet werden können und die "schwache" zivilisierte Welt mit Überfällen heimsuchen. Zwar gibt es vereinzelt Barbaren, die über relativ fortschrittliche Waffen verfügen - zum Beispiel Schwerter und Äxte - und sie können auch gelegentlich Städte erobern oder sogar eigene Städte gründen, dennoch bleiben sie im Herzen stets räuberische Nomaden, die alles zerstören, was sich ihnen in den Weg stellt. Barbaren lassen sich nicht beschwichtigen und auch nicht mit sich handeln - deshalb sollten sie möglichst schnell vernichtet werden, bevor sie eine ernsthafte Bedrohung darstellen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Il termine "barbaro" venne coniato dai Greci e inizialmente veniva utilizzato per indicare qualsiasi straniero. Da allora, la parola ha assunto una connotazione negativa e viene associato a quelle civiltà definite "inferiori". I Cinesi, per esempio, identificavano tutte le culture straniere come "barbare" dai Manciù ai Turchi agli Europei. Roma bollò con questo termine gli Unni e le popolazioni germaniche, così come i Galli che erano culturalmente evoluti.[PARAGRAPH:2]In Civilization IV, questo termine indica le popolazioni che non fanno parte di una civiltà organizzata, vecchi cacciatori che predano i "deboli" nel mondo. Malgrado alcuni barbari abbiano conquistato armamenti più evoluti come spade e asce, e talvolta possano conquistare o fondare delle città, i Barbari rimangono prevalentemente nomadi che distruggono e saccheggiano tutto ciò che capita a tiro. Non si può trattare con i Barbari: devono essere distrutti prima che loro distruggano te!
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]El término "bárbaro" fue acuñado por los griegos, y originalmente se utilizaba para referirse a cualquier extranjero. Pero desde entonces ha adquirido unas connotaciones negativas, pues suele emplearse al hablar de las civilizaciones a las que se considera "inferiores" a la propia. Los chinos, por ejemplo, pensaban que todas las culturas extranjeras (desde los manchúes a los turcos, pasando por los europeos) eran bárbaras. En Roma se empleaba el término para referirse a los hunos y las tribus germanas, así como a los galos, que eran más avanzados.[PARAGRAPH:2]En Civilization IV, este término engloba a todos los pueblos que no forman parte de ninguna civilización organizada del juego, y en lugar de eso se componen de cazadores-recolectores que atacan al "débil" mundo civilizado. Aunque algunos bárbaros pueden llegar a adquirir armas bastante avanzadas (espadas y hachas, por ejemplo), y aunque de vez en cuando pueden capturar ciudades o construir las suyas propias, en el fondo siguen siendo unos nómadas bandidos que lo destruyen todo a su paso. No se puede negociar con ellos, ni es posible aplacarlos: ¡hay que destruirlos antes de que ellos te destruyan a ti!
